awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adjustable-Voltage-Ratio Magnetoelectric Transformer: A New Voltage Conversion and Control Device for Smart Grids
awd_abstract_narration:
Voltage conversion (i.e., converting voltage from one level to another) and control (i.e., regulating voltage within a certain range around the nominal value) is an important issue for the secure, economic operation of modern power grids, particularly future smart power grids with significant penetration of renewable energy resources.  In current power grids, on-load tap-changing (OLTC) electromagnetic transformers, and step-voltage regulators have been commonly used for voltage conversion and control.  However, the tap-changing mechanisms used in OLTC transformers and step-voltage regulators are typically a mechanical mechanism or an electromechanical mechanism with a slow response and can only adjust the voltage ratio of the transformer or regulator in discrete steps.  Therefore, OLTC transformers and step-voltage regulators cannot meet the requirement for flexible, continuous, and fast-acting voltage conversion or control for future smart power grids.  The current alternative is the solid-state transformer (SST).  However, SSTs are currently still limited by voltage and power ratings of the solid-state devices and available circuit topologies.  Moreover, when compared to traditional electromagnetic transformers, SSTs would require more complicated and expensive thermal management and may have a shorter life expectancy.  This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will explore and prove a novel concept for a magnetoelectric transformer with a continuous and quickly adjustable voltage ratio for flexible, fast-acting voltage conversion and control to help secure the electricity supply, accommodate more renewable energy integration, and reduce the cost of electricity delivery.  In addition, the project team will build a thriving, diversified electric power and energy program through the integration of graduate and undergraduate research and teaching with K-12 outreach.  The program will provide a unique platform for training a new generation of young professionals to accommodate the changing environment and meet the emerging workforce and educational needs of the U.S. power and energy industry.

The research goal of this project is to develop a complete framework for designing, prototyping, modeling, controlling, operating, and demonstrating a novel adjustable-voltage-ratio (AVR) magnetoelectric transformer for flexible, continuous, and fast-acting voltage conversion and control of power grids.  The new capabilities of the proposed concept will be achieved through the development of: (1) a new voltage-controlled magnetoelectric device with an adjustable permeability to control the magnetic flux in the transformer, (2) a new transformer configuration for the integration of the flux control devices, and (3) new models and methods for controlling the voltage ratio of the transformer by regulating the magnetic flux using the new flux control devices in the transformer.  This project will provide an innovative and transformative solution for overcoming the existing limitations of existing voltage conversion and control devices used in power grids.  The physical and operating principles to be established and the models and design framework to be created for the new AVR transformer will build a solid theoretical foundation for future development and application of the proposed concept in power grids.  Once the proposed concept is proven by this project, further development and deployment of the concept will require new advancements in different disciplines, such as electrical engineering, material science and engineering, system and control engineering, and mechanical engineering, thus stimulating the creation of new interdisciplinary research.  The findings of this project will impact the control and operation of the future power grids, and will contribute to the creation of a smart power grid to provide better electric energy security, efficiency, and sustainability.

por.por_cntn:
Under the support of this NSF CAREER project, the principal investigator has developed an integrated research and education program focusing on novel electric power conversion and control devices and systems with a long-term goal of contributing to electric energy security, efficiency, and sustainability.  To address challenges in voltage regulation and fault ride through of modern power grids, particularly those with significant penetration of distributed energy resources, the team of this project has created new magnetoelectric devices, including adjustable-voltage-ratio transformers, tunable inductors, and fault current limiters for flexible, continuous, and fast-acting voltage conversion and control and fault protection of the power grids.  The physical and operating principles established, the models and design frameworks developed, the prototypes fabricated, and the simulation and experimental test results obtained for the new magnetoelectric devices formed a solid foundation for further research and development of potential applications of the proposed innovations.  The findings of this project will impact the control and operation of the next-generation power grids and other applications using transformers, inductors, and controllable magnetic devices.  The outcomes of this project also will stimulate research on new magnetoelectric materials and new manufacturing technologies for the proposed innovations in electric power conversion, control, conditioning, and fault protection applications.

 

The findings of this project have generated 10 peer-reviewed papers published in top-ranked journals, 12 peer-reviewed conference proceedings papers, and six Ph.D. dissertations.  One Ph.D. student worked on this project won the Second-Place Prize of the IEEE Vehicular Technology Society Global Motor Vehicles Challenge in 2019.  The principal investigator and graduate students worked on this project have developed seminar materials on novel magnetoelectric devices. The seminar materials have been used for training graduate and undergraduate students and professionals. The funding of this project has helped the development of three-dimensional printing and laser cutting facilities for fabricating magnetic devices as well as an experimental test bed for testing magnetic devices for electric power conversion, control, and fault protection applications.

 

The principal investigator has renovated and enhanced the electric power curriculum at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln through the integration of state-of-the-art technologies and the results of this research.  The undergraduate Electric Machines course was renovated by adding new lecture material and design projects.  A new course, Numerical Analysis, was developed for graduate students and another new course, Electric Drives, was developed for senior undergraduate and graduate students.  Additionally, the principal investigator developed lecture videos for the Electric Machines course and Power Electronics course as well as online resources, including online homework assignments and submission, online student project assignment and presentation, online exams and quizzes, online grading for assignments, exams, and quizzes, etc. during COVID.  The lecture videos and online resources provide opportunities for students to learn remotely and more flexibility for students in learning.  The enhanced curriculum and the integration of research and education have attracted more young individuals to the electric power engineering profession.  The enrollments of electric power courses have always been the highest among all electrical engineering major courses at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln over the course of this project.  This project has generated extensive new knowledge and experimental data on the new magnetic devices developed.  The data provide excellent information resources for teaching and research in the field.  The outcomes of this project will help create a future smarter power grid to accommodate more sustainable energy resources, provide more flexible, cost-effective service to customers, and enhance electric energy security, reliability, flexibility, and sustainability.
